clinical_study.brief_title: The BEACH Study- Interviews With Pregnant and Lactating Women
clinical_study.official_title: The Breastfeeding and Early Child Health (BEACH) Interview Study

brief_summary.textblock: Interview pregnant and lactating mothers in the Gainesville, FL area to optimize; clinical study recruitment and retention, patient-centered outcomes, and stool collection procedures.

detailed_description.textblock: This is an interview study that will enroll mothers during 26 weeks or greater of pregnancy and lactating mothers less than 1 year. The focus of the interviews will assess recruitment, patient-centered outcomes, and stool collection procedures via individualized interviews and data collection. Participants will be recruited from the greater North Central Florida area. Data collection will include questionnaires/surveys as well as minimal risk non-invasive biological samples such as stool, human milk, saliva, vaginal swab, and urine collection. Participants will be seen at the University of Florida Clinical and Translational Science Institute.

primary_outcome.measure: Strategies for recruiting and retaining pregnant women and lactating mothers into clinical research studies (CRTs) will be measured by way of interview.
primary_outcome.description: Interviews will be analyzed to determine the efficacy of common strategies used to recruit pregnant and new mothers to CRTs, challenges or barriers that would preclude women from enrolling and participating in CRTs, their preferences for incentives, as well their preference and methods related to non-invasive sample collection.

secondary_outcome.measure: Measure bioactive compounds in human milk (HM) via Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA)
Quantify the infant intestinal gene expression profile in stool by real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR)
Measure the infant intestinal gene expression profile in stool via whole genome sequencing (WGS)

arm_group.description: (1) 18 years old or over, (2) between 26-38 weeks of pregnancy, (3) live in Florida, and (4) are committed to exclusively breastfeeding.
(1) 18 years old or over, (2) lactating with an infant less than 12 months, (3) live in Florida, and (4) are committed to exclusively breastfeeding.
(1) 18 years old or over, (2) live in Florida, and (3) are pregnant or a new mother (gave birth < 1 year), and are committed to exclusively breastfeeding.

intervention.description: Pregnant women will be interviewed and asked to provide feedback on common strategies used for recruitment, challenges that would preclude them from enrolling and participating in CRTs, their preferences for incentives, and preferences for methods related to non-invasive sample collection. The following will be collected during the interview: self-reported behavioral data, maternal fasting human milk (HM), and maternal- infant microbiome collection.

Lactating mothers will be interviewed and asked to provide feedback on common strategies used for recruitment, challenges that would preclude them from enrolling and participating in CRTs, their preferences for incentives, and preferences for methods related to non-invasive sample collection.

A demographically diverse sample (N = 100) will be recruited via Qualtrics panel management.The sample will be comprised of pregnant (n = 50) and new mothers (n = 50), of which 30% of each group will be Latina women. Participants will be asked to complete a brief survey, asked to provide qualitative feedback on retention strategies, and later be remunerated for their time and participation.

biospec_descr.textblock: Non-invasive biospecimens include stool, saliva, blood, urine, human milk, and vaginal swab.

study_pop.textblock: Participants will be recruited via regional area hospitals through their OBGYN and snowball sampling techniques.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Females 18>45, between 26-38 weeks pregnant, anticipating delivery are area hospitals, live in Florida, and committed to exclusively breastfeeding.
- Females 18>45, activity lactating for <12 months, committed to exclusive breastfeeding. Living in Florida
Exclusion Criteria:
- Smoking
- Pre-eclampsia
- History of pre-term delivery (<35 weeks)
- Only one breast capable of lactation and milk production inadequate
- Any maternal antibiotics in the last 2 weeks during delivery
- Any alcohol consumption
- Drug use

patient_data.ipd_description: In accordance with the NIH Data Sharing Policy of award 1U24DK097193, all data generated by Southeast Center for Integrated Metabolomics (SECIM), along with the corresponding metadata, will be deposited into the NIH Metabolomics Data Repository and Coordinating Center (DRCC) as soon as all quality control steps are completed. Data will be embargoed for one year and, after the expiration of the embargo, made visible to the scientific community regardless of publication status for the data.
